‚òéÔ∏è Need support? Contact Crisis Text Line
.
.
üíö Shout is an affiliate of Crisis Text Line¬Æ in the UK that provides free, confidential support, 24/7 via text. It‚Äôs the first free 24/7 texting service in the UK for anyone in crisis anytime, anywhere via the medium people already use and trust. Here‚Äôs how it works:
.
üì± First, you‚Äôre in crisis. That doesn‚Äôt just mean suicide: it‚Äôs any painful emotion for which you need support. You text Crisis Text Line at 85258.
.
.
üí¨ Your opening message can say anything: The opt-in words you see advertised ("HELLO," "START") just help them know where people are learning about them!
.
.
üëã The first two responses are automated. They tell you that you're being connected with a Crisis Volunteer and invite you to share a bit more. The Crisis Volunteer is a trained volunteer, not a professional. They can provide support, but not medical advice.
.
.
üïë It usually takes around five minutes to connect you with a Crisis Volunteer (It may take longer during high-traffic times).
.
.
üí¨ When you‚Äôve reached a Crisis Volunteer, they‚Äôll introduce themselves, reflect on what you‚Äôve said, and invite you to share at your own pace.
.
.
Find out more by visiting .
.
.
‚ùó If you are feeling like ending your life, please call 999 or go to A&E and ask for the contact of the nearest crisis resolution team. These are teams of mental health care professionals who work with people in severe distress.
.
.
üíö The Mental Health Foundation is a charity specialising in research and policy development, with a focus on preventing mental health problems. We are not able to advise people directly on their personal circumstances.
.
.
üíö Sending all of our care and support from the MHF team.

üéÑA very Merry Christmas to all our incredible supporters, from everyone here at the MHF team. You mean a lot to usüéÅ
.
.
üíöAnd a little reminder that you and your mental health still matter at Christmas!
.
‚òéÔ∏èIf you need support today remember that @Samaritans are available 24/7 for you to call for free on 116 123. .
.
#MentalHealth #MentalHealthAwareness #MentalHealthAtChristmas #ChristmasDay

üéÑA little reminder that YOU and YOUR mental health still matter this Christmas.üíö
.
.
‚òéÔ∏èNeed support?
@Samaritanscharity are available 24/7 for free on 116 123 (UK). Whatever you're going through, they're here to face it with you.
.
.
üíªFor more information on getting support for your mental health visit mentalhealth.org.uk/getting-help
.
.
.
.
.
#Christmas #ChristmasAndMentalHealth #MentalHealth #MentalHealthAwareness #SelfCare

‚òéÔ∏è Need support? Contact a Samaritan. üíö @samaritanscharity are there for you any time day or night. Whatever you're going through, you can call them any time, from any phone for FREE. üíö If you need someone to talk to, they listen. They won't judge or tell you what to do. .
.
‚ùî If you are concerned that you are developing a mental health problem you should seek the advice and support of your GP as a matter of priority. If you are in distress and need immediate help and are unable to see a GP, you should visit your local A&E. üíª visit .
.
.
üíö The Mental Health Foundation is a charity specialising in research and policy development, with a focus on preventing mental health problems. We are not able to advise people directly on their personal circumstances.
.
.
üíö Sending all of our care and support for the weekend, the MHF team.
.
.
.
.
.
#MentalHealth #MentalHealthAwareness #MentalHealthSupport #SupportLines #Samaritans

üíöWe want to dedicate this post to our amazing supporter Bazz.
.
üéàBazz decided to celebrate his 49th and 50th birthdays by holding two Facebook fundraisers for us. He has shared his story to encourage others to do the same!
.
üëèNow it‚Äôs over to Bazz...
.
üí¨‚ÄùMental health is one of those things we all have and many have been affected by. The mind is no different to a car. Both experience some faults occasionally and need diagnosing and often action. If your car was playing up you wouldn‚Äôt just carry on as normal, would you?
.
üí¨‚ÄùI have personally lost several work colleagues, acquaintances and good friends, to suicide within the last 18 months ‚Äì most within a year of my age. Most, if not all were probably avoidable, so I decided ‚Äì enough is enough.
.
üéÅ‚ÄùWhilst we all love receiving a little attention on our birthdays, I would rather have my ‚Äònearest and dearest‚Äô around me. That is why I decided to raise awareness, whenever I can, so that people understand ‚Äúit‚Äôs ok not to be ok‚Äù and that my door is always open ‚Äì metaphorically and physically.
.
üíö‚ÄùInstead of a card, present, or pint on my birthday I have asked my social media friends to donate to the Mental Health Foundation. This helps raise overall awareness, but also provides vital funds to amplify the message.
.
ü§©‚ÄùWe all put on a brave face, smile and joke with those around us, but do we truly know what is going on in each other‚Äôs lives? .
.
üëÇüèΩ‚ÄùJust being there to listen and supporting someone in need is far more important than a birthday card or meaningless gift‚Ä¶ .
.
ü§ù‚ÄùThis is why I would encourage everyone to simply start a Facebook fundraiser and ask friends for donations!
.
.
üíªVisit mentalhealth.org.uk/stories to read more about Bazz and to learn how to hold your own Facebook fundraiser.
.
.
.
.
‚òéÔ∏èNeed support? @samaritanscharity are available 24/7 for free on 116 123 (UK). Whatever you‚Äôre going through, they‚Äôre here to face it with you.

üíöYou and you mental health still matter at ChristmasüéÑ
.
‚òÉÔ∏èThe festive period can be a joyful time of year, filled with festivities, food, parties and time with loved ones. ‚õÑÔ∏èHowever, for some people, it can be a really tough time of year. .
.
üéÖüèºChristmas can bring feelings of obligation and over-commitment. Some people may experience loneliness and isolation and others may find the disruption to routine destabilising.
.
üíöSo we asked you, and our colleagues ‚ùì What helps you with your mental health during the holiday period?
.
üí≠You responded with advice under the four questions below. As always your advice was filled with warmth, community and care:
.
üî∂ Reframing - how can you be your friend this Christmas and turn the volume down on the inner critic?
.
üî∑ Boundaries - what is your agenda and how can you remind  yourself that you have permission to say no?
.
üî∂ Plan - what do you want to do this Christmas and what is really important to you?.
.
üî∑ Actions - what self-care and day to day activities can you keep doing? .
.
üíª visit mentalhealth.org.uk/christmas to read the answers.
.
.
üéÑSpread kindness this Christmas as it can be a hard time of year for many.
.
.
.
‚òéÔ∏è Need support? @samaritanscharity are available 24/7 for free on 116 123 (UK) and whatever you‚Äôre going through, they‚Äôre here to face it with you. .
.
.
.
#MentalHealth #MentalHealthAwareness #Christmas #ChristmasTips #SelfCareTips #christmasandmentalhealth

üíöRepost ‚Ä¢ @allontheboard ‚Ä™üëçThis is just a friendly reminder for those who forgot or have had a lot on their minds to head out and vote. üó£üì£‚úèÔ∏è‚úîÔ∏è@allontheboard ‚Ä¨
.
.
.
‚Ä™#GeneralElection2019 #GE2109 #ElectionDay #allontheboard ‚Ä¨

üó£Your voice üíö Your mental health ‚úèÔ∏èYour vote matters üì£
.
‚úîÔ∏è If you can vote today, then do it anytime up to 10pm ‚è∞
.
.
.
#GE2019 #GeneralElection #yourvotematters

üåüExciting news üåü The theme for #MentalHealthAwarenessWeek 18-24 May 2020 is üí§ 'sleep'.
.
üò¥The Week will focus on the connections between our sleep - or lack of it - and mental health.
.
2Ô∏è‚É£0Ô∏è‚É£üåüThe Mental Health Foundation has set the theme, organised and hosted the week for the last 20 years, during which the event has grown to engage millions of people across the UK and globally, and this is all thanks to you for getting involvedüëè.
.
‚ùìWhy has sleep been chosen as next year's theme:
üí§It was chosen because millions of people report problems with sleeping.
.
üìöEvidence clearly shows it can have a major impact on our mental health. The week will focus on providing information and advice and campaigning for change to improve wellbeing and recovery. .
.
üí¨‚ÄúSleep is the unsung hero for our mental health,‚Äù said Mark Rowland, Chief Executive of the Foundation. .
.
üí°‚ÄúBy understanding what affects our sleep, we can help protect the mental health of millions of people and also support recovery. üì£‚ÄúWe want to start a national conversation about how we can all sleep better ‚Äì and uncover the hidden mental health costs of the poor sleep that affects so many of us.
.
ü§ù‚ÄúWe will investigate the changes we need to make, as individuals, communities and as a society, to get the rest and renewal we all need. We‚Äôll also set out what our schools, universities, employers and policymakers can do to achieve that aim.‚Äù Mark Rowland, Chief Executive
.
üíöWe cannot wait for you to join in with the campaign next year.
.
. üò¥ Find out more by visiting mentalhealth.org.uk/news.
.
. ‚òéÔ∏è Need support?
Remember that @samaritanscharity are available 24/7 for free on 116 123 (UK). Whatever you're going through, they're hear to face it with you.
.
.
.
.
.
.
#Sleep #MentalHealthAwarenessWeek #MentalHealthAwarenessWeek2020 #SleepAndMentalHealth #MentalHealthAwareness #sleepcampaign

‚ùìWhat advice would you give to someone feeling lonely over the festive period?üéÑ
.
‚òÉÔ∏èThe festive period can be a time of excitement, or a time of overwhelm, a time of quality time, or a time of social pressure, a time of connection or a time of loneliness, or all of these things... what the festive period means will be individual to each of us. .
.
üíöWe want YOU to know that YOU and YOUR mental health still matter at Christmas. Here at the Mental Health Foundation we care about YOU. ü§ù
.
üì£We would like you to share and spread this message of compassion during the festive period, which is why we are asking you:
.
üí¨What advice would you give to someone feeling lonely during this time?
.
.
üî∏Loneliness itself is not a mental health problem, but our research shows a correlation between loneliness and anxiety, depression and other mental health problems.
.
üî∏Loneliness is an issue we all wish we didn‚Äôt have to face and loneliness is not just the experience for those who find themselves in isolation. Many of us have experienced loneliness in the context of a busy office or lively party. And many people who choose to be alone don't experience loneliness. It is about quality of relationships, not just quantity.
.
üíöHaving the courage to share our feelings of loneliness, if this is the right thing to do for us, can be one of the biggest first steps we can take. It can create the opportunity for understanding and an invitation for others to be honest about their own experiences.
.
üìùWe will create a helpful blog full filled with all of your tips to help you cope with loneliness over the festive period. Thank you in advance for engaging & supporting each other. All our care, the MHF team.
.
.
‚òéÔ∏èNeed support?
Remember that @samaritanscharity are available 24/7 for free on 116 123 (UK) & whatever you're going through they're here to face it with you.
.
.
üíªEngaging with an online community can be a great source of connection. You may find like-minded people who are experiencing mental ill-health too. This may help to reduce feelings of loneliness & help you to feel understood. Visit @mindcharity üêòElefriends elefriends.org.uk/

‚òéÔ∏è Need support? Contact Crisis Text Line
.
.
üíö Shout is an affiliate of Crisis Text Line¬Æ in the UK that provides free, confidential support, 24/7 via text. It‚Äôs the first free 24/7 texting service in the UK for anyone in crisis anytime, anywhere via the medium people already use and trust. Here‚Äôs how it works:
.
üì± First, you‚Äôre in crisis. That doesn‚Äôt just mean suicide: it‚Äôs any painful emotion for which you need support. You text Crisis Text Line at 85258.
.
.
üí¨ Your opening message can say anything: The opt-in words you see advertised ("HELLO," "START") just help them know where people are learning about them!
.
.
üëã The first two responses are automated. They tell you that you're being connected with a Crisis Volunteer and invite you to share a bit more. The Crisis Volunteer is a trained volunteer, not a professional. They can provide support, but not medical advice.
.
.
üïë It usually takes around five minutes to connect you with a Crisis Volunteer (It may take longer during high-traffic times).
.
.
üí¨ When you‚Äôve reached a Crisis Volunteer, they‚Äôll introduce themselves, reflect on what you‚Äôve said, and invite you to share at your own pace.
.
.
Find out more by visiting .
.
.
‚ùó If you are feeling like ending your life, please call 999 or go to A&E and ask for the contact of the nearest crisis resolution team. These are teams of mental health care professionals who work with people in severe distress.
.
.
üíö The Mental Health Foundation is a charity specialising in research and policy development, with a focus on preventing mental health problems. We are not able to advise people directly on their personal circumstances.
.
.
üíö Sending all of our care and support from the MHF team.

üéÑGive thanks this December to somebody who has helped you with your mental health üéÅ
.
.
üåèWe know that acts of kindness can make the world a happier place - so why not tag someone, be that a friend, family member, colleague or organisation and tell them why you are thankful for their support?
.
.
üòäThis random act of kindness could do you good. There is a strong relationship between the wellbeing, happiness and longevity of those of us who are compassionate. Doing good can help reduce stress and improve your emotional wellbeing. This is true across our lives.
.
.
üí¨"My name is David and I‚Äôm Head of Empowerment and Social Inclusion here at the Mental Health Foundation. I‚Äôm one of the charity‚Äôs longest-serving members of staff, but this is my first opportunity to thank you directly for your support; I hope we can count on your kindness again this Christmas. When it comes to the Mental Health Foundation, I have so much to be thankful for.
.
.
üí¨"Since I joined the Foundation, I‚Äôve had the privilege of seeing and being involved in many advances in the field of mental health. But my connection goes back a whole lot further because without this pioneering charity and enlightened supporters like you, attitudes towards people with mental health problems would be very different ‚Äì and my life could have been very different too.
.
.
üí¨"You see, while today I am a mental health professional invited to sit as an expert on advisory panels at government level, I was once a very scared 15-year-old, with a diagnosis of schizophrenia and a sense that my life was over."
.
.
A personal note of thanks from one of our longest-serving staff members to you, his life is one of many you have touched with your support.
.
.
üíöFind out more about how 'Doing good does you good' by visiting: mentalhealth.org.uk/publications
.
.
üìñRead David's story by visiting mentalhealth.org.uk/stoties
.
. ‚òéÔ∏è Need support?
@samaritanscharity are available 24/7 for free on 116 123 (UK) and whatever you're going through, they're here to face it with you.
.
.
üíª Want to find out more about getting help for your mental health and how to access it, then visit mentalhealth.org.uk/getting-help.

‚òéÔ∏è Need support? Contact Crisis Text Line
.
.
üíö Shout is an affiliate of Crisis Text Line¬Æ in the UK that provides free, confidential support, 24/7 via text. It‚Äôs the first free 24/7 texting service in the UK for anyone in crisis anytime, anywhere via the medium people already use and trust. Here‚Äôs how it works:
.
üì± First, you‚Äôre in crisis. That doesn‚Äôt just mean suicide: it‚Äôs any painful emotion for which you need support. You text Crisis Text Line at 85258.
.
.
üí¨ Your opening message can say anything: The opt-in words you see advertised ("HELLO," "START") just help them know where people are learning about them!
.
.
üëã The first two responses are automated. They tell you that you're being connected with a Crisis Volunteer and invite you to share a bit more. The Crisis Volunteer is a trained volunteer, not a professional. They can provide support, but not medical advice.
.
.
üïë It usually takes around five minutes to connect you with a Crisis Volunteer (It may take longer during high-traffic times).
.
.
üí¨ When you‚Äôve reached a Crisis Volunteer, they‚Äôll introduce themselves, reflect on what you‚Äôve said, and invite you to share at your own pace.
.
.
Find out more by visiting .
.
.
‚ùó If you are feeling like ending your life, please call 999 or go to A&E and ask for the contact of the nearest crisis resolution team. These are teams of mental health care professionals who work with people in severe distress.
.
.
üíö The Mental Health Foundation is a charity specialising in research and policy development, with a focus on preventing mental health problems. We are not able to advise people directly on their personal circumstances.
.
.
üíö Sending all of our care and support from the MHF team.

üèÉ"In March 2020, six of the recruits from SAS: Who Dares Wins will be running 250km through the hot and humid rainforests of Sri Lanka. That's six marathons in five days.
.
.
üë®"Why? Because in 2018 alone, almost 5,000 men took their own life. That's 94 men a week, 13 a day, one every two hours. Suicide remains the single biggest killer of men under 45 in the UK.
.
.
üó£Ô∏è"Men find it hard to be open and honest about their feelings. But we want to change the way men feel about expressing their vulnerability.
.
.
üíö"So, we're taking on this challenge to raise money for the Mental Health Foundation, and raise awareness of mental health issues and the stigma surrounding talking about them.
.
.
üì¢"We believe change is possible but we all have a responsibility to help. So, if you would like to help us champion this hugely important cause, please donate. We would be grateful for anything you can spare.
.
.
ü§ù"Together we can make a difference. Together we can save lives."üí∞justgiving.com/fundraising/sasultrax
.
.
üëèA huge thank you from everyone at the Mental Health Foundation to: James McCorkindale, Milo Mackin, James Gwinnett, Michael Maisey, Richard Allen, Mark Peart for taking on this challenge, for raising money, for making this powerful video and lastly for caring passionately about men's mental health.
.
.
üé•Video produced and Filmed by George Bishop.
.
.
** A note on language in the video: the Mental Health Foundation would encourage individuals not to use the phrasing 'commited suicide' as the use of the word ‚Äúcommitted‚Äù originates when suicide was considered a crime. Instead we would encourage people to say ‚Äútook his/her own life‚Äù, ‚Äúended his/her own life‚Äù, or ‚Äúcompleted suicide‚Äù.
.
.
‚òéÔ∏èNeed support?
The CALMzone are a charity dedicated to men's mental health. They have a helpline which is available 365 days a year 5pm-midnight. Call them on 0800 58 58 58 (UK).
Samaritans are available 24/7 for free on 116 123 (UK). Whatever you're going through, a Samaritan will face it with you.
If you yourself are feeling like ending your life, please call 999 or go to A&E and ask for the contact of the nearest crisis resolution team.
.
.
#MensMentalHealth #Movember #sas

üí¨"To begin with, I have seen first-hand how many close friends and family have had difficulty with their mental health without realising the little things they can do to help themselves.
.
*Trigger warning - this story mentions suicide*
.
üí¨"I‚Äôve also seen how mental ill health can really shake a family. In August 2018, my uncle Stephen lost the battle with his mental ill health at the age of 29. The following months were the hardest that our family had ever had to endure and for most of us the pain is still as raw as it was on the first day. We were rocked to our very cores, everything changed. The worst thing about it is that we aren‚Äôt the only ones.
.
üíö"Stephen was more than an uncle to me, he was a mentor, a man that I idolised growing up and, most definitely, a friend. .
.
‚úîÔ∏è"It is now that I am making the conscious steps to change the way that mental health is viewed and spoken about on a national scale. Young people need to learn things like how to speak openly about emotions, where they can go for help, how they can help to keep other minds healthy and, most importantly, how to keep their own minds healthy.
.
üöó"A car is an interesting way to describe the mental health of an individual, it has lots of parts that require little ingredients to run smoothly. Just as our mental health does ‚Äì these ingredients could be anything, no matter how small or large, and they vary from person to person.
.
üìö"I see mental ill health as a monster that people run away from. Although I think it is time to turn around and stop running. We need to fight this monster. It starts with education."
.
Thank you @nath_jacko1 for being so open and honest with us all üëèüíö üíªRead Nathan's story by clicking on the image: mentalhealth.org.uk/stories
.
. ‚òéÔ∏èNeed support?
Remember that @samaritanscharity are available 24/7 for free on 116 123 (UK) and whatever you're going through, they're there to face it with you. ‚ùìWant to find out more about getting help for your mental health? They visit http://mentalhealth.org.uk/getting-help
.
.
.
.
.
#MensMentalHealth #MensMentalHealthMonth #MentalHealthAwareness #MentalHealthEducation #makeitcount

üö∂On 31 July 2019, Ben Garcia completed a 1,236-mile walk from John o' Groats in Scotland to Land's End in Cornwall. .
.
üåÑBen tells us about his amazing mental health journey which took him from the kitchen of a top UK restaurant to a mountain in New Zealand and saw him spend three months trekking the length of the UK in support of the Mental Health Foundation. üëè Thank you Ben!üíö
.
.
üí¨"My life has been turbulent, but one constant is how I feel when I‚Äôm out in nature, and the further I went along the trail, like a nomad with nothing but the bag on my back, the more at peace I felt, and the stresses from my life just washed away. I was left with who I truly am: someone who is happy and outgoing, who laughs a lot and has an open heart.üå≥
.
.
üí¨"Walking allows me not just to connect to the beautiful outdoors ‚Äì and I really did get to see the best the UK has to offer ‚Äì but also to myself. This has always been great for my mental health and I‚Äôd recommend it to anyone who is struggling. üçÉ
.
.
üí¨"Life for me is still a roller-coaster. It has its ups and downs, highs and lows, but I now have the tools to thrive and to enjoy life to its fullest.
.
.
üí¨"Walking in nature truly has enabled me to manage my mental wellbeing and to prevent myself from falling once again into the clutches of mental ill-health."üíö
.
.
üìñRead Ben's full story this Men's Mental Health Month by visiting mentahealth.org.uk/stories
.
.
‚òéÔ∏è Need support?
@samaritanscharity are available 24/7 for free on 116 123 (UK). If you need someone to talk to, they listen. They won't judge or tell you what to do.
.
.
.
#MensMentalHealthMonth #MensMentalHealth #Movember #MentalHealthAndNature #WalkingAndMentalHealth #MentalHealthAwareness

‚òéÔ∏è Need support? Contact a Samaritan. üíö @samaritanscharity are there for you any time day or night. Whatever you're going through, you can call them any time, from any phone for FREE. üíö If you need someone to talk to, they listen. They won't judge or tell you what to do. .
.
‚ùî If you are concerned that you are developing a mental health problem you should seek the advice and support of your GP as a matter of priority. If you are in distress and need immediate help and are unable to see a GP, you should visit your local A&E. üíª visit .
.
.
üíö The Mental Health Foundation is a charity specialising in research and policy development, with a focus on preventing mental health problems. We are not able to advise people directly on their personal circumstances.
.
.

.

üåüWe launched our new strategy for 2020-2025: Making Prevention Happen. .
.
üíö Prevention is at the heart of what we do. .
.
‚ùìBut, what does prevention even mean and why does it matter? üìñFind our more at - mentalhealth.org.uk/prevention .
.
.
.
.
#MakingPreventionHappen #MentalHealth #MentalHealthAwareness #MentalHealthPrevention #fridaythoughts

‚ú®Today, we launch our new strategy for 2020-2025: Making Prevention Happen.üíö
.
‚ùìBut, what does prevention even mean and why does it matter?
.
üë§We all have mental health. But not all of us live with good mental health.
.
üó£Despite our mental health being such an important personal and social resource, the extent of mental health problems in the population means that too many of us are struggling, rather than thriving and reaching our full potential. This is why we must start talking about prevention and mental health.
.
‚ùìTo learn how we can prevent mental health problems, we need to search for answers to this fundamental question: what causes mental health problems? .
.
üß¨Our biology is important, as it shapes the way our bodies respond to what happens to us. However, having a purely biomedical approach does not consider the effect of the environment on our mental health. In almost all cases, our genes do nothing more than carry a slight risk. What is more important to look at is the wide range of social, economic, family and emotional factors that interact with our genes and our biology. .
.
üíöüíöBeyond genes, our mental health is fundamentally effected by two sets of circumstances:
üî∏The deeply personal experiences that define us. Our mental health can be influenced by our family, our relationships and how we see ourselves. üî∏The social circumstances we find ourselves in. This includes poverty, violence and employment. .
.
üç∞Mental health is complex. There is not, nor will there be, any biomedical test that can predict what combination of personal history and current circumstances determines a person‚Äôs unique state of wellbeing. .
.
üíöüíöüíöThere are three types of prevention:
üî∏Primary prevention: preventing problems before they emerge
üî∏Secondary prevention: prevention for people exposed to inequality üî∏Tertiary prevention: prevention for those already experiencing problems
.
.

üë®Today is #InternationalMensDay and we want to celebrate male mental health role models.üèÖ
.
.
üì£Now, it‚Äôs over to you - who is your male mental health role model‚ùì
.
üí¨Either create your own post of appreciation and tag @mentalhealth or comment on this post. .
.
üî∏üîπüîπüîπüîπüîπüîπüîπIn England, around 1 in 8 men have a common mental health problem. However, men may be less likely to seek support for their mental health or chat about their mental health problems with mates, colleagues or loved ones. .
.
üó£Ô∏èIt is YOUR stories that continually inspire us and keep us working hard towards a world with good mental health for all, including men and boys. It is YOUR stories that inspire others to fundraise and raise awareness for men‚Äôs mental health. It is YOUR stories that help other men experiencing mental health problems feel less alone. .
.
üì£‚ÄúIt is YOUR voice that will help the Mental Health Foundation continue to work towards reaching the stage where us men feel comfortable to discuss our mental health.‚Äùüíö Mark Rowland, Chief Executive, Mental Health Foundation
.
.
ü§ùLet‚Äôs collectively talk about men‚Äôs mental health. üó£Ô∏èShout about your male mental health role model today‚Ä¶
.
.
üë®Throughout all of November, we focus on men's mental health. This is a campaign for anyone who identifies as male or a man and whose mental health may be impacted by pressures associated with this. üíªFind out more: mentalhealth.org,uk/campaigns
.
.
‚òéÔ∏èNeed support?
If you are feeling like ending your life, please call 999 or go to A&E and ask for the contact of the nearest crisis resolution team. These are teams of mental health care professionals who work with people in severe distress. .
.
If you need someone to talk to then @samaritanscharity are available on 116 123 (UK) for free, 24/7. They are there to talk to, listen and they won't judge or tell you what to do. .
.
@calmzone have a national helpline for men to talk about any troubles they are feeling. Call 0800 58 58 58 (UK). They are available 5pm-midnight 365 days a year.
.
.
.
.
.
#MensMentalHealthMonth #Movember #InternationalMensDay #MensMentalHealth #MentalHealthAwareness

‚òéÔ∏è Need support? Contact Crisis Text Line
.
.
üíö Shout is an affiliate of Crisis Text Line¬Æ in the UK that provides free, confidential support, 24/7 via text. It‚Äôs the first free 24/7 texting service in the UK for anyone in crisis anytime, anywhere via the medium people already use and trust. Here‚Äôs how it works:
.
üì± First, you‚Äôre in crisis. That doesn‚Äôt just mean suicide: it‚Äôs any painful emotion for which you need support. You text Crisis Text Line at 85258.
.
.
üí¨ Your opening message can say anything: The opt-in words you see advertised ("HELLO," "START") just help them know where people are learning about them!
.
.
üëã The first two responses are automated. They tell you that you're being connected with a Crisis Volunteer and invite you to share a bit more. The Crisis Volunteer is a trained volunteer, not a professional. They can provide support, but not medical advice.
.
.
üïë It usually takes around five minutes to connect you with a Crisis Volunteer (It may take longer during high-traffic times).
.
.
üí¨ When you‚Äôve reached a Crisis Volunteer, they‚Äôll introduce themselves, reflect on what you‚Äôve said, and invite you to share at your own pace.
.
.
Find out more by visiting .
.
.
‚ùó If you are feeling like ending your life, please call 999 or go to A&E and ask for the contact of the nearest crisis resolution team. These are teams of mental health care professionals who work with people in severe distress.
.
.
üíö The Mental Health Foundation is a charity specialising in research and policy development, with a focus on preventing mental health problems. We are not able to advise people directly on their personal circumstances.
.
.
üíö Sending all of our care and support from the MHF team.

üó£Ô∏èI want to share my story and inspire others to get the help they need.
.
*Trigger warning - this post discusses suicide*
.
.
.üë±Richard experienced suicidal thoughts from a young age.
.
üóØÔ∏è"I wish that I had reached out and sought help sooner that I did. I wish I would have had the courage to chat about my situation, my feelings and those suicidal feelings, but I didn't have the courage to do that until I was 28, maybe 30. Maybe if my sister Sonia had done that she'd still be with us.
.
. üå∂Ô∏è"This is why I am getting behind the Curry & Chaat initiative, not only because I think they create a great environment for you to mix with, speak to, or chat to like minded individuals, but also because it is a great opportunity to raise money for a great cause, because this is not going away and neither should it, I think it is something that we should all be encouraged to speak about and not be judged when sharing some of the challenges or negative self talk or suicidal thoughts we might have, or whatever it is that is going on for youüíö
.
. üó®Ô∏è"So I would encourage you to get along and if you feel the urge maybe create your own event to raise some of this much needed money for such a fantastic cause." .
.
üå∂Ô∏èüíªFind out more about the Curry & Chaat campaign by visiting mentalhealth.org.uk/curryandchaat.
.
‚òéÔ∏èNeed support
You can call @samaritanscharity for free, at any time 24/7 on 116 123. They are there to listen. You can also email jo@samaritans.org
.
üîπNeed immediate help
If you yourself are feeling like ending your life, please call 999 or got to A&E and ask for the contact of the nearest crisis resolution team. These are teams of mental health care professionals who work with people in severe distress.
.
üíöSending all our care and support the MHF team.
.
.

üó£Ô∏èWe want you to join us in sharing the Mental Health Foundation's General Election manifesto 2019. ü§ùTogether, let‚Äôs tell the next UK government what we want to see from them on preventing mental health problems.
.
üì¢ Join our movement. üì± Share our graphics. üó£Ô∏è Spread the message.
.
üî∏üîπüîπüîπüîπüîπEvery week in England, one in six adults experiences a common mental health problem, such as anxiety or depression, and, at some point in their lives, one in five adults has considered taking their own life.
.
‚§¥Ô∏èThe huge and growing number of mental health problems places an unmanageable strain on the NHS.
.
‚§µÔ∏èWe must reduce the levels of mental distress among our friends & family and that we face as individuals by addressing the causes of mental health problems. We cannot only treat our way out of this mental health crisis.
.
‚ùóThe current high rates of preventable poor mental health would be considered unacceptable in any other area of health, and we shouldn‚Äôt accept them for mental health.
.
üíöThe next government has the opportunity to build on our growing understanding of the factors that lead to poor mental health and deliver a thorough, cross-government plan which tackles the root causes of mental health problems and improves the wellbeing of our nation. .
.
‚úîÔ∏èOur manifesto presents five actions the next UK government can take to work towards better mental health for all.
.
.
üì£5 Actions to Prevent Mental Health Problems:
.
1Ô∏è‚É£Create a cross-government plan to address the causes of mental health problems. This would involve all government departments working together to prevent mental health problems and to promote better mental health.
.
2Ô∏è‚É£Give our children a mentally healthy start in life. .
.
3Ô∏è‚É£Restore local authority funding so that local government can effectively carry out its public health functions.
.
4Ô∏è‚É£Identify what is being done to protect and promote people's mental health and where more work is needed.
.
5Ô∏è‚É£Support public services to understand and respond appropriately to trauma. .
.
üíªRead the full manifesto: mentalhealth.org.uk/publications
.
.
.
#GeneralElection2019 #MHFManifesto #mentalhealth

üåçToday is #WorldKindnessDay. What small act of kindness have you done for someone else‚ùì
.
.
üéÅYou may recognise the expression that it is better to give than receive but did you know that this is backed up by research?
.
.
ü§ùThere is a strong relationship between the well-being, happiness and longevity of those of us who are compassionate. .
.
üíöDoing good can help reduce stress and improve your emotional wellbeing. This is true across our lives.
.
.
üèÉWe all have so much going on in our lives, lots of strains and stresses, and we are currently living in a combative political atmosphere. Being kind can get pushed to one side, in favour of what is urgent or what is trending now. .
.
üôèBut taking time to be kind to other people can make you feel good, help reduce stress and be beneficial for your own emotional wellbeing.
.
.
‚úîÔ∏èAs part of the Mental Health Foundation‚Äôs work to help people lead mentally healthy lives, we have produced the guide 'Doing good does you good' to show the positive impact that helping others can have on your own mental health, including some tips and suggestions to help you get started. .
.
‚òï So, take a few minutes, have a read and think about doing something for a friend or a stranger today on World Kindness Day: www.mentalhealth.org.uk/publications/doing-good-does-you-good
.
.
‚òéÔ∏èNeed support?
Samaritans are available 24/7 for free on 116 123 (UK). If you need someone to talk to, they listen. They won't judge or tell you what to do.
.
.
.
.
.
.
.
.
#WorldKindnessDay #DoingGoodDoesYouGood #RandomActsOfKindness #MentalHealth #MentalHealthAwareness
